title: Trump travel ban: President attacks 'so political' courts
text:
Is Trump's immigration order legal? 
Addressing police chiefs on Wednesday morning, Mr Trump began by reading from the Immigration and Nationality Act, the law empowering the president authority to oversee migration. 
"It was written beautifully," Mr Trump said, adding that even "a bad high school student would understand this". 
"I don't ever want to call a court biased, so I won't call it biased," the president said. 
He added: "Courts seem to be so political and it would be so great for our justice system if they would be able to read a statement and do what's right. Media caption Why did an Iraq veteran give a stranger his Purple Heart medal? 
"And that has to do with the security of our country, which is so important." 
He continued: "It's sad, I think it's a sad day." 
Mr Trump also said: "I was a good student. I understand things. I comprehend very well. OK? Better than, I think, almost anybody." 
During his remarks, the president also said a Boston federal judge who had ruled in favour of his policy was a "highly respected" and "perfect" jurist. 
Mr Trump also referred to his immigration ban as a "weapon". 
"We have to give you the weapons that you need," he told police chiefs, "and this is a weapon that you need and they're trying to take it away from you, maybe because of politics or maybe because of political views." Media caption Lancaster, Pennsylvania: America's refugee capital 
Also on Wednesday morning, Mr Trump criticised retailer Nordstrom after it decided not to stock her new clothing line. 
"My daughter Ivanka has been treated so unfairly by @Nordstrom. She is a great person - always pushing me to do the right thing! Terrible!" Mr Trump tweeted. 
Shares of the retailer fell 0.7%, before rallying slightly. 
In Tuesday's hearing, the San Francisco-based 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals posed tough questions at those challenging and defending Mr Trump's travel ban. 
The court is expected to issue a ruling as early as Wednesday. Image copyright AP Image caption Mr Trump criticised Nordstrom after it decided not to stock Ivanka Trump's new clothing line 
But the case will probably end up at the Supreme Court, the nation's top judicial body. 
The court must decide whether Mr Trump acted within his authority or violated the US Constitution's prohibition on laws favouring one religion over another, as well as anti-discrimination laws. 
The 9th Circuit is expected to rule on whether a lower court judge in Seattle - whom Mr Trump called a "so-called judge" - acted properly in temporarily halting enforcement of the president's order. 
Mr Trump's 27 January order seeks to bar travellers from Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen from entering the US for 90 days. 
It would also ban all refugees for 120 days and indefinitely exclude those from Syria. 
Democrats and other critics have said Mr Trump's comments about the judiciary attack a core principle of US democracy that courts are supposed to be independent. 
The judiciary is a co-equal branch of the US government, along with Congress and the president's executive branch, under the Constitution.
